prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
These are unresolved band 7 continuum observations of z~2 star forming galaxies, with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request the most compact configuration, at its resolution of 1.1 arcsec these high-z galaxies are effectively point sources.
We have estimated 850um fluxes from stellar mass, star formation rate, and redshift using the Herschel-based mean SED=f(z,M*,SFR) of Magnelli et al. 2013. The temperature of individual SEDs may vary around these nominal ones. To ensure complete detections to compare dust masses to our CO data we hence require at least 10 sigma detection for the nominal SED.
To minimize overheads, we have grouped sources into science goals defined by a field and a point source RMS, such that this SNR condition is met for the faintest source in each science goal. We keep a minimum on-source time of 3 minutes to avoid unfavourable observation/overhead ratios.
We have checked that there is no overlap with the z > 2 COSMOS sources observed in the Scoville et al Cycle 0 program, which was aimed at a mass-selected sample above 10^11 solar masses, irrespective of their SFR. That program therefore included many objects that lie well below the Main Sequence. Our galaxies are generally at lower masses (see Fig 1) and are on or very near the Main Sequence. Our science goals require individual detections of each source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to measure total dust masses in 27 Main Sequence galaxies at 2 < z < 2.5 for which we are obtaining CO measurements and other diagnostics of the gas content, including star-formation rates, metallicities and gas outflows. Our goal is to use this combined 5-dimensional data to build up a self-consistent picture of the mass and atomic/molecular state of the gas and thereby better understand the cosmological regulation of star-formation in Main Sequence galaxies. We will also investigate and isolate possible systematic effects arising from the lower metallicities of these gas- rich systems. This comprehensive data set of high quality measurements on a representative sample of galaxies will also be important for calibrating other less extensive data or those obtained at lower signal to noise.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
